comment: Use standard English instead of "ab initio".
Consider "in accordance with" or "under" instead of "according to".
Replace "action or proceeding" with "proceeding".
Clarify "affiliate". At the time the contract was signed? When a provision is applied?
citations: GTE Wireless, Inc. v. Cellexis Int'l, Inc., 341 F.3d 1 (1st Cir. 2003)

comment: If "agreement" is used as an agreement title, use a more descriptive title if possible. Consider "contract".
Replace "Agreement and Plan of Merger" with "Merger Agreement".
Replace "Agreement of Purchase and Sale" with "Purchase Agreement" or "Sale Agreement".
Use standard English instead of "allocatur".
Replace "allonge" with "indorsement supplement", "indorsement addendum", or "indorsement certificate",
In an introductory clause, replace "among" with "between".
Avoid "anniversary" for milestones in months or weeks.
Be more specific than "annual meeting".
citations: Airgas, Inc. v. Air Products & Chemicals Inc., 8 A.3d 1182 (Del. 2010).

comment: When "applicable" precedes a noun, consider omitting or use of a more precise term.
Consider "apply".

phrases: arising out of or relating to
comment: In a dispute resolution provision, state precisely the types of claims, consider "relating to", and clearly describe the relevant subject matter. Also consider excluding extracontractual liability.
citations: In re TFT-LCD (Flat Panel) Antitrust Litigation, No. M 07-1827 S1, 2011 WL 2650689 (N.D. Cal. July 6, 2011)
Henderson v. Henderson Investment Properties, L.L.C., 147 Idaho 638, 227 P.3d 568 (2010)

comment: Replace "Articles of Merger" with "Merger Agreement".
To require compliance, "as amended" serves no purpose. To refer to a provision or definition, replace with "as in effect on the date of this agreement" or "as in effect at any time".

phrases: as liquidated damages and not as a penalty
comment: When providing for liquidated damages, explain why liquidated damages are appropriate and why damages are difficult to estimate.
citations: Restatement (Second) of Contracts ยง356 cmt. c (1981)
Ludlow Valve Manuf. Co. v. City of Chicago, 181 Ill. App. 388 (1913)

comment: Consider "as applicable" and "whichever applies" instead of "as the case may be".
When effecting an attornment, replace "attorn" with "consent" and consider "attornment" as a section heading. Under Canadian law, see notes in MSCD.
Consider omitting "automatically". When expressing a legal fiction, replace with "deem".
Clarify whether "because" refers to a sole cause.
citations: Gross v. FBL Financial Servs., Inc., 557 U.S. 167 (2009)

comment: "To the best of X's knowledge" is the same as "to X's knowledge".
Omit "binding agreement" from introductory clauses.
Use standard English instead of "bona fide".
Replace "records". Consider "accounting records" or "financial records". When referencing the Delaware General Corporation Law, consider "in accordance with" the statute.
Replace "buy" with "purchase".
Replace "Buy-Sell Agreement" with "Shareholders' Agreement" or a variant.
In an introductory clause, replace "by and between" with "between".
Replace "by-laws" with "bylaws".
Consider whether "certain" might suggest a narrower subset than you intend.
Replace "Certificate of Merger" with "Merger Agreement".
Consider requiring mere notice instead of certification.
Ensure that "change in control" is consistent with "change of control".
Consider "competing" or "to compete" instead of "competitive".
Consider omitting "complete and accurate" or replacing it with "accurate".
Consider addressing concerns about remote damages more directly, such as by waiver of "remote" or "speculative" damages or by describing what damages are permitting.
In a recital of consideration, "consideration" accomplishes nothing, and is usually inaccurate. Consider "in exchange for".
Do not use "continuance" to mean "duration".
"Contractual" is an awkward mouthful.
Replace "contractual arrangements" with "contracts".
Replace "contractual instruments" with "contracts".
Replace "contractual obligations" with "contract obligations".
Replace "contractual terms" with "contract terms".
Use standard English instead of "contra proferentem".
Consider replacing "costs and expenses" with "expenses", "court costs", "other litigation costs", or "any other expenses".
Terminology like "coupled with an interest" is not controlling. Consider reciting an interest.
The phrase "deemed incorporated by reference" accomplishes nothing.
Use standard English instead of "de facto".
Considering defining "Potential Event of Default".
Consider defining "default".
Use standard English instead of "de jure".
Use standard English instead of "de minimis".
Use standard English instead of "de novo".
The phrase "desires to" is oddly steamy. Consider "wants to" instead.
Consider alternatives to "disclaim" like "exclude" and "modify".
The phrase "due or to become due" is archaic.
Consider omitting "duly", except in "duly incorporated" and "duly organized".
The word "validly" in "duly and validly" is redundant.
In an introductory clause, address who is an authorized representative in a statement of fact.
Be more specific than "during ... employment".
citations: Mattel, Inc. v. MGA Entertainment, Inc., 616 F.3d 904 (9th Cir. 2010)

phrases: during the term of this agreement
comment: Consider omitting "during the term of this agreement".
Replace the defined term "Effective Date" with "the date of this agreement".
If "effective date" is used as the start date of performance, replace it with "start date".
Use standard English instead of "ejusdem generis".
Replace "end" with "terminate" or "termination".
Omit "especially", or replace with "including" or "specifically".
Replace "execute" with "sign".
Consider omitting "execute and deliver".
Replace "execution" with "signature".
Use standard English instead of "ex gratia".
Use standard English instead of "ex parte".
Replace "facsimile" with "fax".
Omit "or no reason" from "for any or no reason". Consider addressing the lack of an obligation to explain directly.

phrases: for any reason or no reason
comment: Omit "or no reason" from "for any reason or no reason". Consider addressing the lack of an obligation to explain directly.
Consider replacing "forever" with "indefinitely" or "perpetually".
Consider omitting "fixed fee".
Consider omitting "flat fee".
Omit "force" from "force and effect".
Consider omitting "formally".
Consider omitting "formally".
Omit "form and substance". Consider attaching documents as exhibits.
Do not use "for the avoidance of doubt".
Consider restructuring multi-sentence definitions with "for the avoidance of doubt" into a single sentence.
Consider clarifying "fraud".

phrases: from the beginning of the world
comment: Omit "from the beginning of the world".
Omit "from the beginning of time".
Be more specific than "full-time".
Do not use "guarantee" as counterpart of "guarantor".
Replace "guarantee" with a simpler phrase when used as a verb.
Do  not use "guarantees that" for emphasis.
Do not use "guarantees that" together with an obligation.
Replace "guaranty" with "guarantee".
Consider revising "has occurred and is continuing".
Avoid "hereby", except in language of performance.
Omit "hereby" from lead-ins.
Replace "herein" with "in this agreement".
Avoid "hereof".
Do not use "i.e.".
Consider "under" instead of "in accordance with".
Omit "in accordance with this agreement" from recitals.
Replace "timely".
Replace "timely".

phrases: including its affiliates and direct and indirect subsidiaries
comment: Omit "including its affiliates and direct and indirect subsidiaries" from introdutory clauses.
Use "therefore" instead of "in consideration of the premises".
The phrase "incorporated by reference" accomplishes nothing.
The phrase "incorporated by this reference" accomplishes nothing.
The phrase "incorporated herein by reference" accomplishes nothing.
Consider "perpetually" instead of "indefinitely".
"Indefinitely" doesn't make sense of a release.
See commentary.
Consider "contract" instead of "indenture".
State the concept in question clearly enough the first time.
Use "wants to" instead of "intends to".
Consider clarifying "intentional misrepresentation".
Use standard English instead of "inter alia".
Avoid "in particular".
Use standard English instead of "in personam".
Use standard English instead of "in rem".
Use standard English instead of "ipso facto".
Use "wants" instead of "is agreeable to".
Use "wants" instead of "is desirous of".
Replace "is entered into" with "is dated".
Replace "is made" with "is dated".
Do not use "it being understood".
"Joint" is subsumed by "several" in "joint and several".
Address remedies and procedures directly, rather than with "joint".

phrases: know all men by these presents
comment: Omit "know all men by these presents".
Consider defining "knowledge".
The phrase "knowledge and belief" is a meaningless exercise in redundancy.
"Likely" is a slippery, unclear term. Consider stating a percentage probability.
See MSCD.
Replace "lump-sum payment" with "single payment".
Use standard English instead of "mala fides".

phrases: made a part of this agreement
comment: The phrase "made a part of this agreement" accomplishes nothing.
Consider deleting "mere" or replacing it with "just" or "only".
Consider deleting "merely" or replacing it with "just" or "only".
Use standard English instead of "mutatis mutandis".
Omit "now, therefore".
Use standard English instead of "nunc pro tunc".
Consider replacing "on an arm's length basis".
Consider replacing "on a reasonable basis".
Replace "on a daily basis" with "daily" as an adverb, not an adjective.
Use "pro rata" as an adverb, not an adjective.
Use "quarterly" as an adverb, not an adjective.
Replace "on a regular basis" with "regularly".
Replace "on a timely basis" with "timely" as an adverb.
Replace "on a weekly basis" with "weekly" as an adverb.
Replace "on a yearly basis" with "yearly" as an adverb.
When "on behalf of" the other members of a corporate group, consider alternatives.
In an introductory clause, "organized and validly existing" should be addressed instead in a statement of fact.
Use standard English instead of "pacta sunt servanda".
Use standard English instead of "parens patriae".
Use standard English instead of "pari passu".
Use standard English instead of "per diem".
Use standard English instead of "prima facie".
Use standard English instead of "pro tanto".
Consider a more informative title than "Purchase Agreement", like "Asset Purchase Agreement" or "Securities Purchase Agreement".
Use standard English instead of "qui tam".
Do not use "reasonably likely".
Omit "represented by" referring to a company represented by a division.
Use standard English instead of "res judicata".
Consider a more informative title than "sale agreement", like "Asset Sale Agreement" or "Securities Sale Agreement".
Address remedies and procedures directly, rather than relying on "several".
Use "wants to" instead of "seeks to".
Omit "shall" from "shall be determined", unless creating a legal fiction.
citations: Management Strategies, Inc. v. Housing Authority of City of New Haven, 2009 WL 1958170 (Conn. Super. Ct. June 2, 2009)

phrases: share exchange agreement and plan of exchange
comment: Replace "Share Exchange Agreement and Plan of Exchange" with "Share Exchange Agreement".
Omit "solely" from statement of a party's capacity.
Clarify whether "subsidiary" refers to subsidiaries at the time the contract was signed or when the provision is applied.
Use standard English instead of "sui generis".
Replace "telefacsimile" with "fax".
Replace "telecopier" with "fax".
Replace "telecopy" with "fax".
Telex is all but dead as a means of communication.
Do not use "that is" like "i.e.".

phrases: the other party named in the signature blocks below
comment: The phrase "the other party named in the signature blocks below" comes at expense of readability.
Avoid "thereby".
Avoid "therein".
Avoid "thereof".
Avoid "true and correct" to incorporate recitals by reference.
Replace "twelve-month anniversary" and the like with "anniversary".
Consider replacing "until the end of time" with "indefinitely" or "perpetually".

phrases: upon the terms and conditions and subject to the conditions set forth in this agreement
comment: Omit "upon the terms and conditions and subject to the conditions set forth in this agreement".
Use standard English instead of "ultra vires".
